pygot.gradient.finiteDifference.forward(f, x, h=None, *args)[source]

Forward finite-difference approximation

Parameters:

f: callable

The (scalar) function we wish to find the gradient of

x: array like

parameter value

epsilon: array like

epsilon used to compute the finite difference. Does not have a default value because it is only allowed in python3 but not python2 :( WTF! So we also allow the use of None here to force it to make its own mind up!! (aka default value)

*args: args, optional

Any other arguments that are to be passed to f
Returns:

grad: numpy.ndarray

array of gradient

*args: args, optional

Any other arguments that are to be passed to f
Returns:

array of gradient

pygot.gradient.finiteDifference.richardsonExtrapolation(f, x, epsilon, *args)[source]

Richardson extrapolation under forward finite-difference

Parameters:

f: callable

The (scalar) function we wish to find the gradient of

x: array like

epsilon: array like

epsilon used to compute the finite difference. Does not have a default value because it is only allowed in python3 but not python2 :( WTF! So we also allow the use of None here to force it to make its own mind up!! (aka default value)

*args: args, optional

Any other arguments that are to be passed to f
Returns:

grad: numpy.ndarray

array of gradient

R: numpy.matrix

lower triangle of the extrapolation matrix. First column is the gradient. Difference in diagonal represent the error
pygot.gradient.finiteDifference.forwardHessian(f, x, h=None, *args)[source]

Forward finite-difference approximation of the Hessian

Parameters:

The (scalar) function

x: array like

parameter value

epsilon used to compute the finite difference. Does not have a default value because it is only allowed in python3 but not python2 :( WTF! So we also allow the use of None here to force it to make its own mind up!! (aka default value)

*args: args, optional

Any other arguments that are to be passed to f
Returns:

2d array of the Hessian
pygot.gradient.finiteDifference.forwardGradCallHessian(g, x, h=None, *args)[source]

Forward finite-difference approximation of the Hessian using perturbation on the gradient function

x: array like

parameter value

epsilon used to compute the finite difference. Does not have a default value because it is only allowed in python3 but not python2 :( WTF! So we also allow the use of None here to force it to make its own mind up!! (aka default value)

*args: args, optional

pygot.gradient.simplexGradient.linear(f, x0, h=None, S=None, lb=None, ub=None, *args)[source]

Linear simplex gradient.

Parameters:

f: callable

The (scalar) function we wish to find the gradient of

x0: array like

parameter value at the center of the simplex

S: array like

direct of the simplex

*args: args, optional

Any other arguments that are to be passed to f
Returns:

grad: numpy.ndarray

array of gradient

Notes

Only accepts box constraints at the moment

pygot.gradient.simplexGradient.closestVector(A, x)[source]

Find the closest vector between each row of matrix A and the vector x. Closeness is defined as the smallest angle between two vector

Parameters:

A: array like

matrix of dimension (n,p)

y: array like

vector of dimension (p,)
Returns:

y: numpy.array

The vector closest to x

r: numpy.array

vector of angels in radian

index: int

the index value
